title: AI Insights: Generative AI
description: UK’s Government Digital Service explains that generative AI is a subset of artificial intelligence able to produce text, images or other outputs using probabilistic models trained on large datasets.  The guidance describes how large language models tokenise and embed input text before using transformer networks to generate outputs, and it stresses that these models replicate patterns without true understanding or sentience【263830693408424†L129-L164】.

title: AI Insights: Prompt Engineering
description: This AI Insights guidance introduces prompt engineering – the practice of constructing clear, structured prompts for large language models.  It compares prompts to recipes, emphasising that the data, examples and instructions we provide shape the output, and it explains that well‑designed prompts improve LLM accuracy and safety while vague prompts risk unexpected results【987026297617710†L147-L168】.  The document notes that prompt engineering must prioritise safety by sanitising queries to prevent harmful or unsafe instructions【987026297617710†L157-L179】.

title: Seven lessons in AI (Project Magazine)
description: Association for Project Management author Thomas Bloor distils lessons from organisations experimenting with AI.  He advises leaders to champion AI adoption, run experiments to learn quickly, control risk and evaluate tools, refine solutions through feedback loops, scale successful pilots and invest in skills so that teams are comfortable using AI【647901680357378†L1216-L1323】.

title: A Vision for Data in the Built Environment
description: The Circular Buildings Coalition’s report notes that sustainability reporting in the built environment is fragmented by differing data requirements across regulations, investors and rating schemes.  It calls for a common data dictionary, a federated data model and digital building logbooks to reduce reporting burdens, improve investment decisions and accelerate sustainability; aligning regulatory data requests and investing in digital solutions are among its key recommendations【465574845491609†L40-L89】.

title: A Challenge and an Opportunity: Artificial Intelligence and Automation in the Construction Industry
description: The Construction Industry Training Board’s 2021 research report argues that construction remains a largely manual, low‑automation sector and that digital adoption offers significant productivity gains.  It urges industry leaders to agree on a shared definition of digital construction, share best practice and invest in digital skills so that organisations can exploit AI and automation; without aligned leadership the sector risks missing critical opportunities in the coming years【25624925981092†L168-L194】.

title: ABC AI Tech Report
description: Associated Builders and Contractors’ fourth technology report outlines how artificial intelligence can enhance efficiency and innovation in construction.  The report combines an AI resource guide, essays on AI’s impact and a Hensel Phelps case study showing how the contractor used the Track3D platform to improve project efficiency; industry leaders stress that the report helps contractors learn about AI and machine learning to improve safety, quality and profitability【647128200895249†L97-L152】.

title: AI as Artificial Ignorance
description: Bent Flyvbjerg’s working paper argues that current AI resembles ‘artificial ignorance’ because it can mix true and false statements, producing persuasive output without regard for truth.  He compares AI to ‘bullshit,’ noting that both prioritise rhetoric over accuracy, and warns that users must be sceptical and verify AI outputs rather than accepting them at face value【668124866630108†L124-L139】.  The paper calls for ethical governance and rigorous validation of AI systems.

title: Adopt: Understanding what drives and inhibits deeper use of AI
description: Behavioural Insights Team researchers frame AI adoption as a continuum from no adoption to shallow and deep use.  They argue that adoption is a behavioural process influenced by motivation, capability and trust; barriers such as low salience of benefits, status‑quo bias, friction, cognitive load and psychological threats inhibit adoption, while enablers include implementation intentions, framing benefits concretely, harnessing social norms, operational readiness and transparency【631660795494161†L208-L251】【631660795494161†L305-L349】.

title: Agentic AI – the new frontier in GenAI: An executive playbook
description: PwC’s executive playbook explains that agentic AI – systems where multiple AI agents collaborate autonomously – is poised to make a major economic impact and transform industries.  It highlights key features of agentic AI such as autonomy, goal‑oriented behaviour, environment interaction, learning capability, workflow optimisation and multi‑agent conversation, and argues that organisations should leverage multimodal GenAI while ensuring ethical safeguards to boost efficiency, customer experience and revenue growth【449400178477231†L391-L440】【450617757044478†L58-L114】.

title: Unlocking Cultural Readiness for AI
description: Alexander Budzier’s LinkedIn article argues that AI transformations succeed or fail based on organisational culture rather than algorithms.  He emphasises that culture shifts when behaviours, structures and incentives change, and that AI adoption requires new decision‑making structures, rapid prototyping and empowered teams【733524845409353†L5-L31】.  The article stresses that trust – built through credibility, reliability, intimacy and shared goals – explains much of the variation in digital transformation success and encourages leaders to assess trust deficits and communicate clearly to close them【733524845409353†L59-L89】.

title: AI Augmented Workforce: A Leader’s Guide to Unleashing Human Potential
description:
Scaled Agile Framework’s guidance defines an AI‑augmented workforce as employees using approved AI tools to reduce repetitive tasks, improve quality, drive innovation and focus on creative work; these benefits require employees to have authority, resources and training【466592540908057†L84-L97】.  
The article explains how AI improves job satisfaction and productivity across roles such as Scrum masters, product managers and portfolio leaders, and outlines five steps for leaders to build an AI‑augmented workforce—identify use cases, ensure responsible AI use, measure impact, invest in upskilling and foster a culture of innovation—while warning against burnout, shadow AI and over‑reliance on AI without human oversight【466592540908057†L112-L154】【466592540908057†L270-L329】.

title: AI in EPC Industry White Paper
description:
The International Advisory Partners’ white paper describes how artificial intelligence enhances efficiency, accuracy and safety throughout the engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) project lifecycle.  
It highlights applications such as AI‑driven design optimisation, predictive risk analytics, construction‑site monitoring with drones and computer vision, AI‑based supply‑chain optimisation, defect detection and lifecycle asset management, and includes case studies of Bentley Systems’ GenerativeDesign tool and Komatsu’s SmartConstruction platform【259198907776963†L6-L82】【259198907776963†L85-L170】.

title: AI in the Built World: Investment in AI
description:
A/O Research’s investment report analyses venture funding and adoption trends for AI in the built environment.  
It notes that AI‑enabled built‑world start‑ups in Europe and North America raised US$18.6 billion over the past decade—with $8.6 billion in the last two years—and that London leads by deal count while the Bay Area leads by capital invested; climate technology, ESG reporting and energy assets are the fastest‑growing AI applications alongside AEC software, smart buildings and real‑estate inspection【162411253002142†L93-L137】.  
The report highlights that generative‑AI applications are emerging but face challenges due to heterogeneous, context‑specific data and that digitisation and automation remain short‑term priorities, while AI ecosystems of robotics, IoT, NLP and generative models enable digital transformation and decarbonisation across the built world【162411253002142†L49-L71】【162411253002142†L126-L137】.

title: AI Insights: Agentic AI
description:
This AI Insights guidance defines agentic AI as autonomous systems composed of specialised agents enhanced by large language models that can plan, select tools and execute tasks.  
It explains that agentic systems bring adaptability, extensibility, dynamic routing and improved automation but also create risks such as loss of human oversight, premature deployment, architectural complexity, volatile frameworks, inconsistent outputs, opaque decision‑making and high development costs【629944452317335†L124-L166】【629944452317335†L317-L404】.  
The guidance recommends mitigations including modular composition, interface contracts, explainable AI with audit trails, thorough testing, profiling and alignment with business needs【629944452317335†L404-L563】.

title: AI Insights: Agentic RAG
description:
The AI Insights article introduces agentic Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), explaining that traditional RAG slices documents into vector embeddings for retrieval, while agentic RAG adds autonomy by iteratively identifying gaps and issuing further queries until outputs are complete【109206199018461†L124-L206】.  
It describes how agentic RAG systems refine reports through a cycle of drafting, gap identification and refinement, but warns of risks such as runaway iterative loops, debugging challenges, data quality and bias issues, and language‑model confabulation; robust termination criteria, audit histories and extensive testing are recommended【109206199018461†L208-L263】【109206199018461†L267-L293】.

title: AI Insights: Agentic Workflow
description:
The Government Digital Service explains that agentic workflows introduce autonomous AI agents into traditional workflow systems, allowing dynamic task decomposition, adaptive collaboration and continuous execution across multi‑agent teams【113331796226191†L156-L248】.  
Examples include logistics management, personal scheduling assistants and travel planning; however, risks include a lack of transparency, unintended behaviours and reliance on underlying language models that may hallucinate or embed biases【113331796226191†L275-L322】【113331796226191†L316-L366】.

title: AI Insights: Integrated Agents
description:
This guidance defines integrated agents as AI‑driven assistants or automation tools embedded into software to perform tasks such as drafting documents, managing spreadsheets and scheduling meetings【916045406565647†L121-L134】.  
It distinguishes between agentic AI, traditional software agents and visual agent interfaces, and warns of risks including data leakage, ungoverned automation (shadow IT) and lack of responsible design; guidelines recommend responsible entity creation, clear business justification, validation, inventory maintenance and continuous monitoring of agent behaviour【916045406565647†L136-L280】.

title: AI Insights: Synthetic Data
description:
GDS’s AI Insights piece explains that synthetic data are artificially generated datasets designed to mimic real‑world data while preserving statistical properties, used to address data quality, bias, privacy and rare event issues【326630106798414†L124-L146】.  
It notes that synthetic data help rebalance datasets and simulate rare events but warns that poorly generated data can introduce unrealistic patterns and bias; responsible development requires continuous validation, fairness assessments, version control and documentation【326630106798414†L132-L156】【326630106798414†L183-L236】.  
The article emphasises that synthetic data complement rather than replace real data and must be combined with real‑world testing【326630106798414†L242-L247】.

title: AI Insights: Prompt Risks
description: This spotlight article warns that generative AI systems are vulnerable to “prompt injection” attacks, where malicious instructions hidden in user input or embedded content can override safety rules and extract confidential information.  The guidance explains that static prompt templates are not enough—attackers can manipulate the large language model’s context to reveal secrets or execute unauthorised actions—and that organisations must treat both public and internal systems as attack surfaces.  It highlights “jailbreaking” techniques that circumvent safety constraints and recommends continuous testing, cross‑functional security processes, training and rigorous auditing to limit vulnerabilities and ensure responsible AI use【742378120718611†L164-L273】.

title: AI Insights: Introduction
description: This introductory guidance explains that the AI Insights series is a collection of articles from the Government Digital Service to help UK public sector organisations implement artificial intelligence effectively, safely and securely.  It notes that AI adoption is a priority for government but brings limitations and risks, so the series complements the AI Playbook by covering topics not addressed in the playbook—such as safeguarding, evaluation metrics, prompt engineering, chatbots and agentic systems—and will be updated every two months to reflect policy and technology developments【669465359094656†L123-L163】.  The article emphasises that the content is aimed at both technical and non‑specialist audiences and encourages readers to join cross‑government AI communities and use AI guidance alongside organisational policies【669465359094656†L168-L177】.

title: Artificial Intelligence Playbook: Principles for the UK Government
description: The UK government’s AI Playbook sets out ten principles for responsible AI adoption.  It urges teams to understand what AI can and cannot do and to recognise that current models lack reasoning and contextual awareness; civil servants must learn how to use AI tools safely and test them for accuracy【836031714304758†L331-L343】.  The playbook stresses lawful and ethical use of AI—consulting legal and data protection experts, addressing bias and environmental impact—and insists that AI services be designed to meet security standards, with safeguards against data poisoning, prompt injection and hallucinations【836031714304758†L348-L404】.  Further principles require meaningful human control at appropriate stages, managing the full AI life cycle, choosing the right tool for each job and fostering openness, collaboration and commercial engagement to ensure skills and assurance frameworks are in place【836031714304758†L413-L466】.

title: AI: Powering Productivity in the UK
description: Celonis’s 2025 UK Business Productivity report surveys 500 senior leaders and finds that economic headwinds, employee stress, difficult technology implementation and digital skills gaps are the main barriers to productivity.  Around 39% of respondents say AI‑enabled solutions and process intelligence tools already help employees be more productive, and nearly half of businesses are investing in AI to automate manual processes, reduce errors and free staff for higher‑value tasks【568879877490547†L13-L23】.  The report argues that AI, hybrid working and upskilling can boost growth, and it offers case studies where AI improves quality control, compliance and risk modelling while cautioning that companies must invest in skills and change management to realise these benefits.

title: Roadmap: AI‑Ready Data Essentials
description: Gartner’s roadmap argues that many generative AI projects fail because data is poor quality, ungoverned or misaligned with business goals.  It defines “AI‑ready data” as a continuous practice of aligning, qualifying and governing data and warns that up to 30% of generative‑AI projects will be abandoned due to inadequate data quality, unclear value or high costs【781778272067519†L150-L190】.  The guide presents a five‑stage approach: assess data requirements and prioritise AI use cases; present these needs to leadership for investment and alignment; evolve data practices with metadata, semantics and RAG techniques; extend the data ecosystem with improved literacy and semantics; and scale with cross‑functional governance, continuous quality management and compliance monitoring【781778272067519†L360-L452】.  It emphasises cross‑functional collaboration among CIOs, CDAOs, data engineers, security teams and procurement to build trustworthy, interoperable data.

title: APM BoK 2025: Data Analytics & AI in Project Management
description: This chapter from the Association for Project Management’s Body of Knowledge explains that projects generate large amounts of unstructured and siloed data, and that data analytics and AI can transform this into evidence‑based insights.  It describes how AI improves decision‑making by predicting risks, delays and cost overruns, automates tasks such as scheduling and progress tracking, enhances collaboration and communication and supports cost and time savings【149767134228139†L86-L147】.  The guidance stresses that AI adoption must start with clear use cases and robust data strategies; it highlights ethical concerns, human oversight and environmental impacts, and warns that poor data quality (“rubbish in, rubbish out”) undermines AI outputs【149767134228139†L570-L698】.  It calls for upskilling the workforce, ensuring data availability and comparability across supply chains and measuring progress towards AI‑driven project management.

title: Artificial Intelligence in UK Construction
description: The Civil Engineering Contractors Association’s report on AI in UK construction acknowledges that AI can deliver better design optimisation, improved safety and faster project delivery, but warns of over‑reliance on technology, cybersecurity threats and ethical concerns【636119201477822†L52-L77】.  It offers ten recommendations, including promoting existing AI standards, undertaking a construction‑specific risk review, setting up confidential risk reporting, fostering cross‑industry collaboration through an AI community, developing a coordinated implementation plan, and providing role‑specific training on AI, security and ethics【636119201477822†L84-L109】.  The report emphasises that AI should support human decision‑making rather than replace it and calls on the sector to upskill the workforce and ensure responsible governance.

title: Artificial Intelligence in the Knowledge Economy
description: Economists Enrique Ide and Eduard Talamàs model AI as an algorithm that mimics human knowledge within hierarchical firms to study how AI affects the organisation of work.  They show that AI not only displaces some workers but also changes the way managers and workers are matched: when AI acts as a worker it becomes the most knowledgeable worker supervised by the best humans, and when AI acts as a manager it reorganises firms and alters the matching patterns【891632866940950†L5-L18】.  The paper argues that AI simultaneously substitutes and complements human labour, increasing total labour income but creating winners and losers; organisational effects therefore matter, and AI adoption may expand firm size, shift wages and decentralise decision‑making【891632866940950†L68-L77】.

title: Artificial Intelligence Playbook for the UK Government
description: The UK government’s AI Playbook provides guidance for civil servants using AI.  It sets out ten principles – including knowing what AI is and its limitations, using AI lawfully and ethically, ensuring security, maintaining meaningful human control, managing the AI life cycle, selecting appropriate tools, being open and collaborative, working with commercial colleagues, ensuring skills and expertise, and aligning AI use with organisational policies【382923023187713†L314-L326】.  The playbook cautions that AI systems lack reasoning and may produce inaccurate results, so officials must learn about AI, understand its risks, seek legal and ethical advice, and employ safeguards to mitigate biases, privacy concerns and AI‑specific threats such as data poisoning or prompt injection【382923023187713†L333-L343】【382923023187713†L348-L384】.

title: Business Applications of AI: Framework to Categorise AI Use Cases
description: This briefing from The Alan Turing Institute’s BridgeAI programme presents a framework to help businesses categorise AI use cases.  The framework groups nine categories of information into four dimensions – organisation, AI system, input data and economic sector – to create a structured view of AI opportunities【630208312351526†L352-L358】.  It distinguishes between product‑/service‑centric and process‑centric applications and lists the business functions that AI can support (e.g., accounting, customer service, logistics, HR and research & development)【630208312351526†L465-L502】.  The AI system dimension captures capabilities such as goal‑directed action, recognition and detection, generation, optimisation, prediction and simulation, along with the operating environment (virtual vs physical) and readiness levels from hypothetical to operational【630208312351526†L578-L702】.  The framework highlights that AI adoption potential is highest in sectors like agriculture, construction, creative industries and transportation, which face high deployment costs and skills gaps【630208312351526†L930-L959】.

title: AWS Cloud Adoption Framework for Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Generative AI
description: AWS’s Cloud Adoption Framework for AI (CAF‑AI) outlines a method for organisations to derive business value from AI.  It advises leaders to work backwards from the desired business outcomes, define expected benefits, plan organisational transformation and build foundational capabilities for AI adoption【807889654525422†screenshot】.  The framework emphasises six critical perspectives – business, people, governance, platform, security and operations – and recommends structured assessments, such as Cloud Maturity Assessments and executive briefings, to align AI initiatives with strategic goals【807889654525422†screenshot】.

title: Breaking Away: The Secrets to Scaling Analytics
description: McKinsey’s analysis highlights that fewer than 20% of organisations succeed at scaling advanced analytics.  Breakaway companies align on a clear analytics strategy, invest heavily in building data, technology and talent foundations, and focus on the “last mile” of embedding analytics into workflows and decision‑making processes【143094428740186†screenshot】.  Most firms capture small gains from isolated use cases but fail to embed analytics across the business; breakaway firms spend more of their analytics budgets on integration and scaling, enabling them to reap larger productivity benefits【143094428740186†screenshot】.

title: CIOB Artificial Intelligence (AI) Playbook 2024
description: The Chartered Institute of Building’s AI Playbook outlines how artificial intelligence can transform the built environment.  Members of CIOB’s Digital & Innovation Advisory Panel explain that AI offers vast opportunities for designing, constructing, operating and reusing buildings and infrastructure, and they provide insights and practical applications for using AI in construction workplaces【892885371265111†L94-L105】.  The playbook includes a resources section and an AI use case template to help organisations identify business goals, user needs, data sources, expected benefits, risks and evaluation metrics【892885371265111†L107-L156】.

title: AI Insights: Introducing the GDS AI Insights Series
description: The UK Government Digital Service (GDS) launched the AI Insights series to help public‑sector teams use AI safely and effectively.  The introduction explains that this series complements the AI Playbook by exploring topics not covered elsewhere—such as evaluation metrics, safeguarding and agentic AI—and aims to serve both technical specialists and non‑specialists across government.  Articles are published approximately every two months and readers are encouraged to join the cross‑government AI community for support【642783812458816†L24-L80】.

title: Data Governance Toolkit: Navigating Data in the Digital Age
description: The Broadband Commission’s toolkit (July 2025) guides governments and organisations in building rights‑based data governance. It explains how to define a clear vision and purpose for data use that aligns with human‑rights law, co‑develop use‑cases with citizens and stakeholders and ensure strategic alignment across agencies【259090142407965†L1412-L1561】. The toolkit also provides checklists on principles (transparency, accountability, fairness and stewardship), roles (chief data officers, regulators and ethics boards) and lifecycle practices such as data minimisation, metadata standards and meaningful consent【259090142407965†L1019-L1114】. These recommendations help policy‑makers design governance frameworks and build public trust.
barriers: Lack of coherent data governance frameworks and policies
Insufficient stakeholder engagement and participatory design
Poor clarity of roles and responsibilities across the data lifecycle

title: Data Sharing and Innovation Roundtable at the House of Lords
description: This Connected Places Catapult/Digital Twin Hub roundtable (21 July 2025) explored how data sharing can unlock place‑based innovation. Participants agreed that data sharing has evolved from a technical challenge to a strategic imperative; cross‑sector collaboration and narrowly defined use‑cases accelerate progress while infrastructure, standards and skills remain critical enablers【999867150917152†L30-L42】. Strategic insights included the need for clear value propositions, trust‑building processes, SME support, flexible regulation and investment in data literacy【999867150917152†L44-L50】. Immediate priorities highlighted national data leadership, flexible platforms, SME access, digital infrastructure and fair value exchange【999867150917152†L52-L58】.
barriers: Cultural resistance and lack of trust in data sharing
Fragmented leadership and absence of national coordination
Limited infrastructure and skills to support interoperable data platforms

title: Reimagined Development in the Future of Work: 2025 Learning Trends Perspective
description: This McKinsey Research & Innovation Learning Lab study synthesises over 45 trend reports to provide a navigation tool for the future of workplace learning. It highlights three interdependent themes: creating fluid development ecosystems, adopting AI responsibly and building resilient, adaptable organisations. The report argues that successful AI adoption requires a human‑centred vision, cross‑functional governance, AI fluency programmes, and rewards for higher‑order skills【66943689898833†L695-L729】. It warns that resilience and adaptability must be embedded in work structures to prevent burnout and that employers should support a multigenerational workforce through cross‑generational collaboration and continuous reskilling【66943689898833†L745-L783】.
barriers: Insufficient change management and AI literacy programmes
Burnout and lack of support for resilience and adaptability

title: Digital Information in Temporary Organizations
description: In this open‑access journal article, Whyte and Eshraghi examine how temporary organisations – such as projects, events and emergency responses – are shaped by digital information. They note that these organisations access information via generic information systems but exhibit two distinctive features: they use digital information that pre‑exists, is generated during, and persists after the temporary project, and this information is transferred across multiple systems【467477035535434†L23-L29】. The paper argues that digital information accelerates decision‑making and coordination but raises issues around virtualisation, algorithmic content generation and surveillance【467477035535434†L30-L33】, calling for research on how temporary organisations manage digital information across time‑bounded phases【467477035535434†L100-L116】.
barriers: Fragmentation of digital information across multiple systems
Challenges in retaining and transferring data beyond project lifecycles
Concerns over surveillance and algorithmic content generation

title: Digital Transformation and the AI Imperative in Public and Private Sector Projects
description: This Association for Project Management (APM) research report (July 2025) surveys public and private sector project professionals to understand how digital transformation and AI are reshaping project management. Key insights include improved decision‑making through AI‑driven analytics (61% report better decisions), the critical role of data quality and governance, the importance of agile practices and modern digital tools, and the need for strategic project leadership and digital competencies【790081654217139†L325-L369】. The report recommends establishing integrated AI platforms with human oversight, adopting data governance frameworks, tailoring agile methodologies to context, investing in digital skills and responsible AI, and measuring the impact of digital transformation on project performance【790081654217139†L381-L405】.
barriers: Insufficient data quality and governance leading to ‘garbage in, garbage out’
Superficial adoption of agile methodologies without cultural change
Gaps between responsible AI policies and practical implementation

title: Digitalisation in Construction Report 2023 (RICS)
description: RICS’s annual report uses data from the Global Construction Monitor (Q4 2022) to benchmark digital adoption in construction. While digital tools are recognised as essential for addressing climate change and delivering social value, the report warns that adoption is stagnating and areas such as carbon measurement and ESG remain nascent【772581666656925†L137-L155】. Survey respondents cite high cost and effort of change, shortage of skilled workers and lack of clear client demand as the top blockers to digitalisation【772581666656925†L615-L629】. The report calls for collaboration between industry, government and academia, standardised data processes and investment in skills to overcome these systemic barriers and support net‑zero goals【772581666656925†L137-L156】.
barriers: High cost and effort required to adopt digital tools
Shortage of digital skills and expertise within organisations
Lack of clear client demand and unstandardised data processes

title: NESO Digitalisation Strategy & Action Plan (DSAP) June 2025
description: The National Energy System Operator’s June 2025 Digitalisation Strategy & Action Plan details how digitalisation underpins the UK’s transition to a net‑zero energy system. The foreword notes that by strengthening data sharing, embracing early AI adoption and collaborating with customers, NESO can create a more interconnected and efficient energy network【546802702688372†L120-L131】. The strategy outlines six priorities – consumer value, clean power, decarbonised energy, customer centricity, digital mindset and people value – and commits to leveraging data and AI to plan and operate Great Britain’s electricity and gas networks【546802702688372†L144-L156】. It positions NESO as a digital leader tasked with developing secure data‑sharing infrastructure and exploring AI and quantum computing to enhance operational efficiency.
barriers: Need for coordinated national leadership and cross‑sector collaboration
Limited secure data‑sharing infrastructure and interoperability
Challenges of adopting AI and emerging technologies in a regulated energy sector

title: Empowering AI Leadership: AI C‑Suite Toolkit
description: The World Economic Forum’s AI C‑Suite Toolkit (Jan 2022) equips executives to navigate AI’s transformative potential and risks. The executive summary stresses that AI could add $15.7 trillion to global GDP by 2030 but introduces unprecedented risks including bias, malicious attacks and misinformation【256119419996720†L163-L200】. The toolkit urges C‑suite leaders to align AI strategies with corporate goals, integrate AI with digital and data strategies, build a culture that nurtures AI talent and ensure responsible AI governance across design, development, deployment and monitoring【256119419996720†L163-L248】. It is structured into modules covering AI basics, strategy, people and organisation, responsible AI, implementation and AI in sustainable development.
barriers: Lack of aligned AI strategies and roadmaps at executive level
Inadequate ethical governance and risk management for AI
Limited AI literacy and talent within organisations

title: EY US AI Pulse Survey 2025: Why Agentic AI is a Revolution Stuck in an Evolution
description: EY’s 2025 AI Pulse Survey explores enterprise perceptions of agentic AI. It finds that 97% of senior leaders whose organisations invest in AI report positive ROI across functions, yet only 14% have fully implemented agentic AI and 87% identify barriers such as cybersecurity and data‑privacy concerns【589152007710681†L15-L29】. Fear of replacement also contributes to hesitancy, and investment is shifting towards building custom AI solutions in‑house【589152007710681†L20-L37】. The survey notes that while spending on AI is rising and leaders anticipate transformative value, execution lags, highlighting the need for robust governance and alignment.
barriers: Cybersecurity and data‑privacy concerns around agentic AI
Fear of workforce replacement hindering adoption
Misalignment between rising investment and implementation capability

title: Fueling the AI Transformation: Four Key Actions Powering Widespread Value
description: Deloitte’s 2022 ‘State of AI in the Enterprise’ report outlines four actions to unlock value from AI: (1) invest in culture and leadership – high‑performing organisations emphasise cross‑functional collaboration, workforce optimism and change management【610178708010184†L540-L569】; (2) transform operations – redesign workflows and roles to manage risk and integrate AI ethically【610178708010184†L540-L569】; (3) orchestrate technology and talent – acquire and develop AI talent while leveraging off‑the‑shelf platforms; and (4) select high‑value use cases that deliver near‑ and long‑term business value【610178708010184†L83-L109】. The report notes that 94% of leaders view AI as critical over the next five years but many organisations remain underachievers despite increased deployment【610178708010184†L134-L176】, underscoring the need for culture change and human‑machine collaboration.
barriers: Lack of AI‑ready culture and leadership commitment
Unchanged operations and workflows limiting AI value realisation
Insufficient orchestration of technology and talent across the organisation

title: GenAI and the psychology of work
description: A review in Trends in Cognitive Sciences warns that generative AI tools can mimic cognitive, creative and interpersonal skills, challenging human–machine boundaries and reshaping the knowledge, task and social characteristics of work.  The authors stress that while GenAI can improve productivity, it threatens workers’ needs for competence, autonomy and relatedness, leading to coping strategies and potential resistance.  They call for human‑centred workplaces that balance GenAI’s benefits with psychological risks【14784767410509†L307-L317】.

title: Generative AI framework for HM Government
description: The UK government’s Central Digital and Data Office issued a generative‑AI framework built around ten principles: understanding what generative AI is and its limitations, using it lawfully and ethically, securing AI tools, maintaining meaningful human control, managing the AI lifecycle, picking the right tool for the job, being open and collaborative, engaging commercial colleagues early, building skills and expertise, and aligning with organisational policies and assurance.  The framework explains that large language models only predict the next word and lack true understanding, so they can hallucinate, replicate bias and lack domain expertise, meaning organisations should put assurance in place and avoid high‑risk use cases【866773175046722†L14-L33】【866773175046722†L687-L749】.

title: Gleeds AI initiatives (October 2024)
description: Gleeds outlines several internal AI tools to streamline project services.  A project‑execution‑plan assistant analyses best practice to standardise and improve project execution plans, while a bid‑writer AI produces high‑quality tender responses based on templates.  Additional tools include a procurement report generator, a meeting‑minutes AI that combines Teams transcriptions with custom generative summarisation, and a compliance assistant that provides instant access to industry information【178062758083303†L14-L40】. title: These Human Capabilities Complement AIs Shortcomings
description: This MIT Sloan article summarises research by Isabella Loaiza and Roberto Rigobon, which introduces the EPOCH framework  Empathy & emotional intelligence, Presence & connectedness, Opinion/judgment & ethics, Creativity & imagination, and Hope & vision  to identify human capabilities that complement AI. Using O*NET task data, the authors find that tasks relying on these human capabilities are less likely to be automated and correlate with employment growth, whereas tasks with high automation or augmentation risk are associated with job losses288162455168511L108-L129288162455168511L176-L183. The article emphasises that AI struggles with subjective beliefs and creativity, so organisations should design AI strategies that augment and upskill workers rather than replace them288162455168511L60-L69288162455168511L176-L200.
barriers: Overlooking uniquely human capabilities such as empathy, judgment and creativity in AI deployment
Prioritising automation over augmentation may erode worker morale and resilience
Insufficient upskilling opportunities to develop EPOCH capabilities alongside AI adoption

title: Top Strategic Technology Trends for 2025: Agentic AI
description: Gartners 2025 technology trends report highlights agentic AI  goaldriven software entities that autonomously plan and act using memory, planning and tooling. Agentic AI will integrate into assistants, SaaS platforms and IoT devices and is expected to appear in 33% of enterprise applications and 20% of digital storefront interactions by 2028476239108818402L42-L50476239108818402L104-L119. The report notes that agentic AI offers significant productivity gains but poses risks: unknown bots and lowcode agents may proliferate, poor data quality and architecture hinder development, security threats such as smart malware and prompt injection become more severe, and employees may resent autonomous systems476239108818402L288-L326. Gartner advises organisations to implement clear guardrails, robust data governance, and humanled oversight when integrating agentic AI into workflows476239108818402L290-L370.
barriers: Poor data quality and fragmented architectures impede trustworthy agentic AI development
Security vulnerabilities from autonomous agents, including smart malware and prompt injection attacks
Employee resentment and resistance to autonomous systems due to job security concerns

title: The State of Digital and AI Readiness
description: Thoughtworks 2025 report surveys 1,000 senior decisionmakers across public and private sectors to benchmark digital and AI adoption across five pillars: digital products, enterprise modernization, technology management, data modernization and scaling AI973222572507709L28-L40. Organisations are classified as Leaders, Strong Performers, Emerging Players or Late Adopters; only 17% are Leaders who combine a fully aligned businesstechnology strategy, continuous modernization and strategic investment, while 29% remain Emerging or Late Adopters973222572507709L44-L58. The report emphasises that misperceptions about readiness are common and stresses the need for integrated strategies, relentless improvement and realistic selfassessment to achieve digital and AI excellence973222572507709L95-L109.
barriers: Lack of alignment between technology strategy and business goals
Failure to invest continuously in modernization across platforms, data and AI
Unrealistic selfassessment leading to complacency or underinvestment in digital readiness

title: Why do major projects cost so much and take so long? And what can be done about it?
description: The Institution of Civil Engineers 2025 policy paper investigates why major UK infrastructure projects overshoot time and budget. It finds that best practice tools and lessons learnt are not applied consistently across the governments Major Projects Portfolio441006281230273L70-L81. To improve forecasting and accountability, the paper recommends aggregating assurance evaluation data within the National Infrastructure and Service Transformation Authority (NISTA) and creating a searchable repository of lessons, while adopting shouldcost modelling and referenceclass forecasting441006281230273L90-L110. It calls for stronger governance through continued ministerial responsibility for the Ten Year Infrastructure Strategy and a cabinet committee on infrastructure to coordinate decisions, coupled with better data sharing, streamlined assurance, capability building and public engagement to rebuild trust441006281230273L112-L140.
barriers: Inconsistent application of data and best practice across major projects
Lack of centralised leadership and crossgovernment coordination in infrastructure planning
Poor forecasting due to political incentives, underestimation and insufficient data sharing
